title: Trump to discuss criminal justice at South Carolina HBCU Benedict College. Here are 4 thoughts on his visit
text:
CLOSE President Trump told a Pennsylvania crowd that the U.S. is "building a wall in Colorado," although the state does not border Mexico. USA TODAY

Story Highlights Trump gets to celebrate the passage of criminal justice reform

Trump could overshadow a visit by Democratic candidates

Trump might tout his economic successes to a minority audience

Highlight justice reform as a sign of concern for issues that disproportionately affect black voters

President Donald Trump's visit to Benedict College in Columbia, S.C., Friday has raised questions about his motivation for entering the heart of a historically black school, where supporters among the demographic are likely to be few.

What is the political angle? What is there to gain, or potentially, to lose? Both for Trump and the Democratic presidential challengers who will all participate in the weekend's "Second Step Presidential Justice Forum."

The forum, held on the 150-year-old college's campus in the heart of Columbia, will focus on the issue of criminal justice reform. Nine of the highest-profile Democratic candidates will attend on Saturday.

But it will be Trump who has the microphone all to himself on Friday, and the White House says he will address the next step in his criminal justice reform effort, the First Step Act.

Trump: Trump slammed by lawmakers after he called impeachment inquiry a 'lynching'

The new law increased funding for job skill training and expanded pre-release custody qualifications for low-risk inmates, allowing more prisoners of lesser offenses to go free.

It's a law that Trump has embraced as a victory, and Furman University political science professor Danielle Vinson said the appearance at Benedict is an opportunity to celebrate.

"It’s an opportunity for Trump to tout one of his accomplishments, the passage of criminal justice reform last year," Vinson said. "Trump likes to celebrate his victories, and the opportunity to do it in a state where he’s popular but in a venue that many will see as Democratic turf is icing on the cake."

President Donald Trump holds up an executive order to bolster historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) after signing it in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, D.C., on Feb. 28, 2017. (Photo: Jim Watson, AFP/Getty Images)

The president accepted the invitation late in the event's planning stages, well after Democratic candidates — who enjoy overwhelmingly more support in the black community — agreed to participate.

Among the field of 20 in the Democratic primary race, Sen. Cory Booker; South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg; Sen. Kamala Harris; Sen. Bernie Sanders; Sen. Amy Klobuchar and former Vice President Joe Biden will speak as part of the forum on Saturday.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren, former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro and Rep. Tulsi Gabbard will participate on Sunday.

Trump will be long gone by then.

Chip Felkel, a Greenville-based GOP strategist who has been critical of Trump, said he believes the visit is an opportunity to "stick it in the eye of Democratic candidates," who will be overshadowed.

"It's an odd visit," Felkel said. "He's asking for controversy by doing so, but he thrives on it."

Trump enjoys overwhelming support among South Carolina Republican voters, so much so that state party leaders canceled the 2020 primary, and Felkel said there's not much more to gain politically.

"I can't see where he gets a whole lot out of it that he doesn't already have," Felkel said.

However, Clemson University political science professor David Woodard said Trump might have an opportunity to send a broader message beyond South Carolina voters to the nation if he focuses on his argument that the strong economy has benefited minorities more than ever.

"I'm sure that's the gist of his message," Woodard said. “If Republicans could break some of the stranglehold that Democrats have on the black vote, maybe the way to do it is to show the opportunity in free markets.”

From 2018: Black college presidents push for the "next step" after Capitol Hill conference

Woodard said he's not surprised at the visit.

“He’s sort of fearless to walk in the lions," he said. "I think he’s comfortable doing that in states he knows he’s going to win. He’ll probably be more guarded in states that are more contested. I’m not surprised he’s coming to a base state."

The visit is likely more than a victory lap on an issue, said Robert Oldendick, a University of South Carolina political science professor.

“I don’t think it’s just a matter of jumping into a place he’s not wanted," Oldendick said.

The visit could serve as an effort not to gain black voters, but instead to affect their turnout, which Oldendick said was a factor in Trump's victory in 2016 when black voters didn't show up to polls in the same numbers as for former President Barack Obama's two elections.

Benedict College pictured Monday, Oct. 21, 2019. President Donald Trump will attend a criminal justice reform forum at the historically black in Columbia on Friday, Oct. 25. (Photo: Zoe Nicholson/Staff)

Trump will highlight justice reform as a sign of his concern for issues that disproportionately affect black voters, he said.

“He could be doing it more to kind of tamp down the enthusiasm African-Americans might have for the Democratic candidates,’ Oldendick said. “This is one of the achievements that he can point to that resonates popularly in the black community.”

The appearance offers Democrats an opportunity to attack Trump, though that might only be effective depending on what comments the president makes, Oldendick said.

The forum format on a particular subject limits their ability to differentiate themselves because there are so many competing to be heard, he said.

“The Democratic candidates have the same problem with this that they do in the debates,” he said. "For the most part, they’re going to all pose very similar elements in terms of criminal justice reform.”

The Democrats will have to be mindful of their purpose in attending in the first place, before the president announced his appearance, Vinson said. Whether the president goes "off-script" will determine the level of national attention, she said.

"The trick for all the Democrats will be finding a way to communicate their message and contrast themselves with Trump without getting lost in Trump. They don’t want to just respond to him. They have to have their own message and respect the audience and the purpose of the event by addressing criminal justice reform."
